Description: Sycamore fig wood athropoid coffin: the coffin is partly hollowed out from the trunk of a sycamore fig tree trunk and partly constructed frompieces of wood rather roughly joined together. The headdress, as well as the body, is covered with stylized feathers in the 'Rishi' pattern. On the breast is a vulture with outspread wings and beneath this a standard offering written in clumily formed hieroglyphs. The frontal surface of the feet is decorated with two confronted figures of Anubis. The detail has been painted on plaster and is worn. The lid is split longitudinally.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: George Herbert, 5th Earl of Carnarvon
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Thebes (historic - Upper Egypt), Intrusive burial in tomb 46/47
Curator's comments: Published: W. V. Davies in W. V. Davies & L. Schofield (eds.), 'Egypt, the Aegean and the Levant : interconnections in the second millennium BC' (London, 1995), p.148 [pl.32.3]; J.H. Taylor and N.C. Strudwick, Mummies: Death and the Afterlife in Ancient Egypt. Treasures from The British Museum, Santa Ana and London 2005, pp. 50-1, pl. on p. 51.
Bibliographic references: Taylor & Strudwick 2005 / Mummies: Death and the Afterlife in Ancient Egypt (p.50-51)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2005-2008, California, The Bowers Museum, Death and Afterlife in Ancient Egypt
